landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: The complaint alleges a residential tenancy and identifies Defendant as the owner/landlord and Plaintiff as a tenant who began renting on or about July 1, 2022 under a periodic/monthly tenancy and paying $2,200/mo (¶3–5). Those facts adequately plead the landlord–tenant relationship.

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: The complaint alleges affirmative acts (sending a repair person on at least two occasions) and, more importantly, omissions (declining to provide a permanent repair or meaningful remedial efforts despite notice) by Defendant (¶3, ¶7–9, ¶12). Those factual allegations sufficiently plead landlord conduct (acts and failures to act).

substantial_interference.reasoning: The complaint alleges repeated, intermittent drops in indoor temperature to approximately 60°F for several hours, creating cold, uncomfortable and at times unsafe living conditions, and expressly alleges these conditions ‘‘substantially interfered’’ with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment (¶6, ¶11, ¶13, ¶17–18). It also alleges concrete effects (illness, increased utility use) that support a claim of substantial interference.

causation.reasoning: The complaint links the heating failures and resulting harms to Defendant’s conduct by alleging Plaintiff repeatedly notified Defendant, Defendant authorized but did not effectuate durable repairs, and Defendant refused to provide a permanent remedy despite knowing of the problem (¶7–9, ¶12, ¶17, ¶20). Those allegations sufficiently trace the interference to the landlord’s acts/omissions.

damages.reasoning: The complaint pleads specific economic damages (increased electricity bills ~ $150/month for space heaters (¶10, ¶19(a)); out‑of‑pocket medical expenses and three days’ lost wages from bronchitis (¶11, ¶19(b)); and general inconvenience and loss of use (¶19(c))). It also states a present damages total ($1,200) and reserves the right to amend (¶21). Those allegations adequately plead damages.
